organisms it is what we call a symbiote
in order to better understand the coral
sim biome we use confocal microscopy
which allows us to observe the living
Carl in a non-invasive manner much can
be learned from these observations

here only the innate fluorescence of the

red coloring of this healthy coral is
due to the fluorescence of chlorophyll
contained in the end of symbiotic algae
known as symbiodinium these unicellular
organisms provide the Carl with first
synthetic nutrients and the coral in
return provides them with necessary
inorganic materials the blue and green
colors represent the corals own
fluorescent proteins time-lapse imaging
shows as the movement of the polyps and

calling on the surface of call
confocal microscopy can give
high-resolution images by eliminating
light from outside of the focal plane
layers of data from different focal
planes known as Z stacks can be
collected and reassembled into
three-dimensional images confocal images
can clearly show the distribution of
different fluorophores individual red
dots of symbiodinium can be seen the
tentacles and throughout the Cena Sark
the fluorescent protein represented by
the blue color in this Carl seems to be
closely associated with biological
structures containing the masses or
stinging cells using the confocal
microscope also allows us to see inside

coral polyps gastrovascular canal a side

bands of tissue that bind the tentacles
together in a close-up view of coral

of individual coral sounds as docile as
Carl may appear they are actually very
dynamic aside from moving tentacles they
can extend these material filaments from
their mouths in this image combining
fluorescence and transmitted light you
can see the Me's material filaments
moving inside the mouth of this pollen
corals use the extrusion of material
filaments to battle with neighboring
Carl to catch prey or in this case to

this species of rotifer is one we often

coral reefs are among the most
threatened ecosystems on earth as
temperature rises corals lose their
endosymbionts leaving them in a severely
weakened state this process is known as
coral bleaching in order to reverse the
global decline of our lives we need a
greater understanding of the differences
between species and the interactions
between the Carl their endosymbionts and
